author: Selim Algar
title: Eugenie Bouchard suing Queens Tennis Center over concussion
text:
A top Canadian tennis player is delivering a devastating backhand to the United State Tennis Association — filing suit against the organization over an incident in which she slipped and bashed her head in a locker room at the US Open in Queens last month.
Eugenie Bouchard, 21, claims she took the jarring tumble shortly after she finished a doubles match at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows during the Grand Slam tournament, according to her Brooklyn federal lawsuit.
The sinewy blonde said she was caused to “slip and fall on a slippery, foreign and dangerous substance” in the physiotherapy area of the sprawling center’s locker room, according to the filing.
Bouchard says she cracked her head so hard that she suffered a concussion and was forced to withdraw.
The injury was a blow to her hopes of winning because she was still alive in the singles and doubles brackets, the suit states.
Her suit also asserts that her world tennis ranking, currently 39th, has already tumbled 13 spots and will likely plunge further because of her forced inactivity. 
The injury has also forced her to withdraw from several potentially lucrative tournaments, according to court papers.
Bouchard was forced to tearfully retire from a match in progress at the China Open in Beijing after complaining of dizziness earlier this month. The match was her first since the Flushing tumble.
“I thought I was physically ready, but unfortunately, the symptoms of my concussion came back,” Bouchard said after her exit. “I hope to get well soon and look forward to returning next year.”
Her concerned opponent, Andrea Petkovic, said Bouchard told her that since sustaining the concussion, she had frequently experienced dizziness following intense physical activity.
The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages from the USTA and the Queens facility for negligence.
